Claim: Darwinian evolution is philosophy not science
Argument: Unobserved events with no experimental backup are only philosophical ideas

Claim: Darwinian evolution is philosophy not science

Claim: Darwinian evolution is philosophy not science

If evolution really proves that human reasoning is thoroughly unreliable, then evolutionists ought to doubt every belief at which they arrive through reason, including all scientific knowledge, and even evolution itself

Claim: Darwinian evolution is philosophy not science
Argument: The search for evidence to support a theory is prone to confirmation bias. If an entire field is biased toward naturalism to an extent that it blinds itself, it will filter evidence, data, and studies selectively, with a more philosophical approach than a scientific one. Biased Studies citing biased studies create compound error, and any objection invites dismissal

Claim: Darwinian evolution is philosophy not science

Claim: Darwinian evolution is philosophy not science
Argument: Darwin's theory has logical flaws and is therefore hardly in the realm of science

Claim: Darwinian evolution is philosophy not science

Claim: Darwinian evolution is philosophy not science

Claim: Darwinian evolution is philosophy not science

Claim: Darwinian evolution is philosophy not science

Claim: Darwinian evolution is philosophy not science

Natural Selection is a mechanism that has ample scientific evidence supporting it as a means by which evolution occurs in life

Claim: Text-to-image AI generators (like Midjourney and DallE2) are built on models that were mostly trained on images on the Internet. Many people assert that this is theft. Is it so?
Argument: These services in particular are making bank from user subscriptions. Some of that should go to the artists whowillingly or unwillinglycontributed to the model

Claim: Text-to-image AI generators (like Midjourney and DallE2) are built on models that were mostly trained on images on the Internet. Many people assert that this is theft. Is it so?
Argument: Aspects of it are, if not theft, then certainly unethical. A machine that learns using uncredited and uncompensated artwork is essentially a tool being built from parts its owner didn't pay for

Claim: Text-to-image AI generators (like Midjourney and DallE2) are built on models that were mostly trained on images on the Internet. Many people assert that this is theft. Is it so?
Argument: I think the word "Theft" is a bit leading. It's too narrow. Whether or not something is being literally stolen, the ethical ramifications need to be considered

Claim: Text-to-image AI generators (like Midjourney and DallE2) are built on models that were mostly trained on images on the Internet. Many people assert that this is theft. Is it so?
Argument: Many of these datasets use content that was not permitted to be used to train the AI

Claim: Text-to-image AI generators (like Midjourney and DallE2) are built on models that were mostly trained on images on the Internet. Many people assert that this is theft. Is it so?
Argument: The outputs of any particular image can be checked for uniqueness, and rejected if too similar. So this is an implementation detail, and not a wholesale rejection of the premise

Claim: Text-to-image AI generators (like Midjourney and DallE2) are built on models that were mostly trained on images on the Internet. Many people assert that this is theft. Is it so?
Argument: People are more influenced by the works they see than the AI models are. (The number of images a given human can see is orders of magnitude less than what the model has been trained on.) We dont charge the students who study and even mimic other works, we should not hold companies to the same standard

Claim: Text-to-image AI generators (like Midjourney and DallE2) are built on models that were mostly trained on images on the Internet. Many people assert that this is theft. Is it so?
Argument: Art produced by AI is, thus far, derivative and deconstructed, both of which are protected and neither require any compensation on the part of the owners of the original work; e.g. Andy Warhol doesnt owe Campbells anything just because he painted their soup can

Claim: Text-to-image AI generators (like Midjourney and DallE2) are built on models that were mostly trained on images on the Internet. Many people assert that this is theft. Is it so?
Argument: Theft does a lot of heavy lifting as it implies not just the duplication of a product, but for the purpose of enjoying said product without having to pay the creator. A pirated movie is a potential lost sale. Training an AI does duplicate the product, but said product is effectively disassembled for parts so the AI can learn; inside the AI system, the work is no longer there, but is part of the amalgam of collected data

Claim: Text-to-image AI generators (like Midjourney and DallE2) are built on models that were mostly trained on images on the Internet. Many people assert that this is theft. Is it so?
Argument: Training the AI is not that different from humans training themselves. The work is used as a reference to learn techniques, both broad and precise, to create their own works. Copying Mickey Mouse is infringing on copyright. Drawing a mouse in the Disney house style is still an original - if unimaginative - distinct creation

Claim: Religion should be involved in politics
Argument: The involvement of religion in politics is necessary to ensure laws and policies are ethical

Claim: Religion should be involved in politics
Argument: Many countries have deeply religious histories and cultures

Claim: Religion should be involved in politics
Argument: Almost all laws are based on moral beliefs, therefore it is appropriate for religious persons to be involved in politics

Claim: Religion should be involved in politics
Argument: Religion has always been involved in politics, because religion forms our human basis for our moral and ethical framework. For example: It's illegal to murder another human being. This is universally true, and it comes from God. I can cite myriad other examples, in every country on Earth-- even those who specifically have laws that run COUNTER to religious doctrines or ideas. They've done so purposefully

Claim: Religion should be involved in politics
Argument: The involvement of religion in politics would prove detrimental to all religions other than the dominant one claiming monopoly over the truth

Claim: Religion should be involved in politics
Argument: Involving religion in politics is antithetical to the principles of a secular democratic society

Claim: Religion should be involved in politics
Argument: Politics and religion should be put aside. Three aspects of life should NOT co-exist: religion-state-army

Claim: Lottery should be an integral component of democratic political systems
Argument: Politics would be more representative under a lottery system

Claim: Lottery should be an integral component of democratic political systems
Argument: Elections would be run better using a lottery system

Claim: Lottery should be an integral component of democratic political systems
Argument: Politicians elected via lottery would be better at their job

Claim: Lottery should be an integral component of democratic political systems
Argument: This could cause a higher reliance on experts in their respective fields to guide policy decisions, because regular citizens will not have the requisite knowledge to create specific public policies

Claim: Lottery should be an integral component of democratic political systems
Argument: There would be less corruption as every time the lottery happens, all the corruption would leave

Claim: Lottery should be an integral component of democratic political systems
Argument: Political parties would cease to exist, which would be harmful to politics

Claim: Lottery should be an integral component of democratic political systems
Argument: Representatives would not be held accountable for their actions

Claim: Lottery should be an integral component of democratic political systems
Argument: Being appointed to a position of power by lottery would leave many people overwhelmed and unprepared

Claim: Lottery should be an integral component of democratic political systems
Argument: The political tides would turn every time a new "lottery" takes place. It would be impossible to issue a multiple-decade plan for a government

Claim: Social media is helping human relationships
Argument: Social media has made it easier to communicate, improving the quality of communication

Claim: Social media is helping human relationships
Argument: Social media enriches human relationships

Claim: Social media is helping human relationships
Argument: Social media allows users to connect with more people

Claim: Social media is helping human relationships
Argument: Social media damages our face to face relationships

Claim: Social media is helping human relationships
Argument: Social media is shown to induce depression in individuals

Claim: Social media is helping human relationships
Argument: Social media promotes one-sided views and creates polarization
